editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Nayoon Ahn

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

Ascribed variously to George Chapman and George Peele. Cf. Camb. hist., v. 6, p. 40; DNB., etc.
Reproduction of original in British Library.
Imperfect: t.p. badly mutilated, some letters missing.

div.p: The tragedy of Alphonsus emperor of Germany as it hath been very often acted (With great applause) at the private house in Blackfriars by his majesty's servants ▪
London, printed for Humphrey Moseley, and are to be sold at his shop at the prince's arms in st. Paul's churchyard 1614.

div.head: To the reader
div.p: I shall not need to bespeak thee courteous, if thou hast seen this piece presented with all the elegance of life and action on the Blackfriars stage; but if it be a stranger to thee, give me leave to prepare thy acceptation, by telling thee, it was received with general applause, and thy judgement (I doubt not) will be satisfied in the reading.
I will not raise thy expectation further, nor delay thy entertainment by a tedious preface. The design is high, the contrivement subtle, and will deserve thy grave attention in the perusal.

list.head: Dramatis personae.
list.item:
Alphonsus emperor of Germany
The seven electors of the German empire.
King of Bohemia.
Bishop of Mentz.
Bishop of Collen.
Bishop of Tryer.
Palatine of the Rhein.
Duke of Saxon.
Marquess of Brandenburg ▪
Lorenzo de cipres, secretary to the emperor.
Alexander his son, the emperor's page.
Hedewick daughter to the Duke of Saxon.

div.head: Alphonsus emperor of Germany.
div.stage: Enter Alphonsus the emperor in his nightgown, and his shirt, and a torch in his hand, Alexander de Tripes his page following him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.l: Boy, give me the master key of all the doors.
To bed again, and leave me to myself.
Is Richard come? have four electors sworn
To make him keisar in despite of me?
Why then Alphonsus it is time to wake.
No Englishman, thou art too hot at hand,
Too shallow brained to undermine my throne;
The Spanish sun hath purified my wit,
And dried up all gross humours in my head,
That I am sighted as the King of birds,
And can discern thy deepest stratagems .
I am the lawful German emperor,
Chosen, installed, by general consent;
And they may term me tyrant as they please,
I will be King, and tyrant if I please;
For what is empire but a tyranny?
And none but children use it otherwise.
Of seven electors, four are fallen away,
The other three I dare not greatly trust;
My wife is sister to mine enemy,
And therefore wisely to be dealt withal;
But why do I except in special,
When this position must be general,
that no man living must be credited,
Further than tends unto thy proper good.
But to the purpose of my silent walk;
Within this chamber lies my secretary,
Lorenzo de cipres, in whose learned brain
Is all the compass of the world contained;
And as the ignorant and simple age
Of our forefathers, blinded in their zeal,
Received dark answers from Appollo's shrine,
And honoured him as patron of their bliss;
So I, not muffled in simplicity,
Zealous indeed of nothing but my good,
Hast to the augur of my happiness,
To lay the ground of my ensuing wars.
He learns his wisdom, not by flight of birds,
By prying into sacrificed beasts,
By hares that cross the way, by howling wolves,
By gazing on the starry element,
Or vain imaginary calculations;
But from a settled wisdom in itself
Which teacheth to be void of passion.
To be religious as the ravenous wolf,
Who loves the lamb for hunger, and for prey;
To threaten our inferiors with our looks;
To flatter our superiors at our need;
To be an outward saint, an inward devil;
These are the lectures that my master reads.
This key commands all chambers in the court;
Now on a sudden will I try his wit,
I know my coming is unlooked for.
sp.stage: He opens the door and finds Lorenzo sleep a loft.
sp.l: Nay sleep, Lorenzo, I will walk a while.
As nature in the framing of the world,
Ordained there should be nihil vacuum;
Even so methinks his wisdom should contrive,
That all his study should be full of wit,
And every corner stuffed with sentences?
What's this? Plato? Aristotle? tush these are ordinary,
It seems this is a note but newly written.

div.stage: [he reads a note which he finds among his books.
div.p: Una arbusta non alit dvos erithicos; which being granted, the Roman empire will not suffice Alphonsus King of Castille, and Richard Earl of Cornwall his competitor; thy wisdom teacheth thee to cleave to the strongest; Alphonsus is in possession, and therefore the strongest, but he is in hatred with the electors, and men rather honour the sunrising than the sun going down. I marry this is argued like himself, and now methinks he wakes.
div.stage: Lorenzo riseth, and snatches at his sword which hung by his bed side.]

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: What are there thieves within the emperor's court?
Villain thou diest; what mak'st thou in my chamber?

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: How now Lorenzo, wilt thou slay thy lord?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: I do beseech your sacred majesty to pardon me,
I did not know your grace.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Lie down Lorenzo, I will sit by thee,
〈◊〉 is sharp and piercing; tremble not,
Had it been any other but ourselves,
He must have been a villain and a thief.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Alas my lord! what means your excellence,
To walk by night in these so dangerous times?

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Have I not reason now to walk and watch,
When I am compassed with so many foes?
They ward, they watch, they cast, and they conspire ▪
To win confederate princes to their aid,
And batter down the eagle from my crest.
O, my Lorenzo, if thou help me not,
Th' imperial crown is shaken from my head,
And given from me unto an English Earl.
Thou knowest how all things stand as well as we,
Who are our enemies, and who our friends,
Who must be threatened, and who dallied with,
Who won by words, and who by force of arms;
For all the honour I have done to thee.
Now speak, and speak to purpose in the cause;
Nay rest thy body, labour with thy brain,
And of thy words myself will be the scribe.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Why then my lord, take paper, pen and ink ▪
Write first this maxim, it shall do you good.

div.p: 1. A prince must be of the nature of the lion and the fox; but not the one without the other.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: The fox is subtle, but he wanteth force;
The lion strong ▪ but scorneth policy;
I'll imitate Lysander in this point,
And where the lion's hide is thin and scant,
I'll firmly patch it with the foxes fell.
Let it suffice I can be both in one.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.p: 2. A prince above all things must seem devout; but there is nothing so dangerous to his state, as to regard his promise or his oath.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Tush, fear not me, my promise; are sound,
But he that trusts them shall be sure to fail.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Nay my good lord, but that I know your majesty,
To be a ready quickwitted scholar,
I would bestow a comment on the text.
sp.p: 3. Trust not a reconciled friend; for good turns cannot blot out old grudges.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Then must I watch the palatine of the Rhein,
I caused his father to be put to death.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Your highness hath as little cause to trust
The dangerous mighty Duke of Saxony;
You know, you sought to banish him the land;
And as for Cullen, was not he the first
That sent for Richard into Germany?

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: What's thy opinion of the other four?

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: That Bohemie neither cares for one nor other,
But hopes this deadly strife between you twain,
Will cast th' imperial crown upon his head.
For trier and Brandenburg, I think of them
As simple men that wish the common good;
And as for Mentz I need not censure him,
Richard hath chained him in a golden bond,
And saved his life from ignominious death.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Let it suffice, Lorenzo, that I know,
When churfurst Mentz was taken prisoner,
By young victorious Otho Duke of Brunschweig
That Richard Earl of Cornwall did disburse
The ransom of a King, a million,
To save his life, and rid him out of bands,
That sum of gold did fill the Brunschweig bags;
But since myself have rained a golden shower.
Of bright Hungarian 〈◊〉 and crusadoes,
Into the private coffers of the Bishop,
The English angel 〈◊〉 their 〈◊〉 and 〈◊〉;
My crosses bless his coffers ▪ and plead for me,
〈◊〉 voice is mine, bought with ten tun of gold,
And at the meeting of the seven electors,
His princely double-dealing holiness
Will spoil the English emperor of hope.
But I refer these matter to the sequel.
Proceed Lorenzo forward to the next.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: I'm glad your grace hath dealt so cunningly,
sp.p: With that victorious fickle minded prelate; for in election his voice is first but to the next.
sp.l: 4. 'tis more safety for a prince to be feared than loved.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Love is an humour pleaseth him that loves;
Let me be hated, so I please myself .
Love is an humour mild and changeable;
But fear oer graves a reverence in the heart.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.p: 5. To keep an usurped crown, a prince must swear, forswear, poison, murder, and commit all kind of villainies, provided it be cunningly kept from the eye of the world.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: But my Lorenzo that's the hardest point,
It is not for a prince to execute,
Physicians and apothecaries must know,
And service fear or counsel-breaking bribes,
Will from a peasant in an hour extort
Enough to overthrow a monarchy.

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: Therefore my lord set down this sixth and last article.
6. Be always jealous of him that knows your secrets,
And therefore it behooves you credit few;
And when you grow into the least suspect.
With silent cunning must you cut them off.
As for example, Julio Lentulus,
A most renowned Neapolitan,
Gave me this box of poison, was not long
But therewithal I sent him to his grave.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: And what's the special virtue of the same?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: That it is twenty days before it works.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: But what is this?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: This an infection that kills suddenly;
This but a toy to cast a man asleep.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: How? b'ing drunk?

sp.speaker: Loren.
sp.l: No, being smelled unto.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Then smell Lorenzo, I did break thy sleep;
And ▪ for this time, this lecture shall suffice.

sp.speaker: Loraen.
sp.l: What have you done my lord? you've made me safe,
For stirring hence these four and twenty hours.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: I see this charms his senses suddenly.
How now Lorenzo, half asleep already?
Aeneas pilot by the god of dreams,
Was never lulled into a sounder trance;
And now Alphonsus overread thy notes.
These are already at my finger's ends,
And lest the world should find this little schedule,
Thus will I rend the text ▪ and after this,
On my behaviour set so fair a gloss,
That men shall take me for a convertite;
But some may think, I should forget my part,
And have been over rash in renting it,
To put them out of doubt I study sure,
I'll make a backward repetition,
In being jealous of my counsel keepers,
This is the poison that kills suddenly,
So didst thou unto Julius Lentulus,
And blood with blood must be requited thus.
Now am I safe, and no man knows my counsels,
Churfurst of Mentz, if now thou play thy part,
Earning thy gold with cunning workmanship,
Upon the Bemish King's ambition,
Richard shall shamefully fail of his hope,
And I with triumph keep my empery.

div.stage: Enter the King of Bohemia, the Bishops of Mentz, Collen, Trier, the palatine of the Rhein, the Duke of Saxon, the marquess of Brandenburg.

sp.speaker: Bohe.
sp.l: Churfursts and princes of the election,
Since by the adverse fortune of our age,
The sacred and imperial majesty
hath been usurped by open tyranny,
We the seven pillars of the German empire,
To whom successively it doth belong
To make election of our emperors,
Are here assembled to unite a new
Unto her former strength and glorious type,
Our half declining Roman monarchy,
And in that hope, I Henry King of Bohem,
Churfurst and sewer to the emperor,
Do take my seat next to the sacred throne.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: Next seat belongs to Julius Florius
Archbishop of Mentz, chancellor of Germany,
By birth the Duke of fruitful Pomerland.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: The next place in election longs to me,
George Cassimirus Palsgrave of the Rhein,
His highness' taster, and upon my knee
I vow a pure sincere innated zeal
Unto my country, and no wrested hate,
Or private love shall blind mine intellect.

sp.speaker: Collen.
sp.l: Brave Duke of Saxon, Dutch-land's greatest hope,
Stir now or never, let the Spanish tyrant,
That hath dishonoured us, murdered our friends,
And stained this seat with blood of innocents,
At last be chastised with the Saxon sword,
And may Albertus Archbishop of Collen,
Chancelor of Gallia and the fourth elector;
Be thought unworthy of his place and birth,
But he assist thee to his utmost power.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Wisdom ▪ not words, must be the sovereign salve,
To search and heal these grievous festered wounds,
And in that hope Augustus Duke of Saxon,
Arch-marshal to the emperor take my place.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.l: The like doth Frederick Archbishop of trier,
Duke of Lorraine, chancellor of Italy.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: The seventh and last is Joachim Carolus,
Marquess of Brandenburg, overworn with age,
Whose office is to be the treasurer;
But wars have made the coffers like the chair.
Peace bringeth plenty, wars bring poverty;
Grant heavens, this meeting may be to effect,
Establish peace, and cut off tyranny.
sp.stage: Enter the empress Isabella King John's daughter,

sp.speaker: Empress.
sp.l: Pardon my bold intrusion mighty churfursts,
And let my words pierce deeply in your hearts.
O! I beseech you on my bended knees,
I the poor miserable empress,
A stranger in this land, unused to broils,
Wife to the one, and sister to the other
That are competitors for sovereignty;
All that I pray, is, make a quiet end;
Make peace between my husband and my brother.
O think how grief doth stand on either side,
If either party chance to be miss;
My husband is my husband; but my brother,
My heart doth melt to think he should miscarry.
My brother is my brother; but my husband,
Oh how my joints do shake fearing his wrong!
If both should die in these uncertain broils.
O me, why do I live to think upon't!
Bear with my interrupted speeches lords,
Tears stop my voice, your wisdoms know my meaning ▪
Alas I know my brother Richard's heart
Affects not empire, he would rather choose
To make return again to Palestine,
And be a scourge unto the infidels;
As for my lord, he is impatient,
The more my grief, the lesser is my hope,
Yet princes thus he sends you word by me,
He will submit himself to your award,
And labour to amend what is amiss.
All I have said, or can device to say,
Is few words of great worth, make unity ▪

sp.speaker: Bohe ▪
sp.l: Madam, that we have suffered you to kneel so long,
Agrees not with your dignity nor ours;
Thus we excuse it, when we once are set,
In solemn council of election,
We may not rise till somewhat be concluded.
So much for that ▪ touching your earnest sure,
Your majesty doth know how it concern us,
Comfort yourself, as we do hope the best;
but tell us, madam, where's your husband now?

sp.speaker: Empress.
sp.l: I left him at his prayers, good my lord.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: At prayers? Madam, that's a miracle.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: Undoubtedly your highness did mistake;
'Twas sure some book of conjuration;
I think he never said prayer in his life.

sp.speaker: Empress.
sp.l: Ah me, my fear, I fear, will take effect;
Your hate to him, and love unto my brother,
Will break my heart, and spoil th' imperial peace.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: My lord of Saxon, and prince Palatine,
This hard opinion yet is more than needs;
But, gracious madam, leave us to ourselves.

sp.speaker: Empress.
sp.l: I go, and heaven that holds the hearts of Kings,
Direct your counsels unto unity.

sp.speaker: Bohe.
sp.l: Now to the depth of that we have in hand;
This is the question, whether the King of Spain
Shall still continue in the royal throne,
Or yield it up unto Plantagenet,
Or we proceed unto a third election.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: Ere such a viperous bloodthirsty Spaniard
Shall suck the hearts of our nobility,
Th' imperial sword which Saxony doth bear,
Shall be unsheathed to war against the world.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: My hate is more than words can testify,
Slave as he is he murdered my father.

sp.speaker: Coll.
sp.l: Prince Richard is the champion of the world,
Learned, and mild, fit for the government.

sp.speaker: Bohe.
sp.l: And what have we to do with Englishmen?
They are divided from our continent.
But now that we may orderly proceed
To our high office of election,
To you my lord of Mentz it doth belong,
Having first voice in this imperial synod,
To name a worthy man for emperor.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: It may be thought, most grave and reverend princes,
That in respect of divers sums of gold,
Which Richard of mere charitable love,
Not as a bribe, but as a deed of alms,
Disbursed for me unto the Duke of Brunschweig,
That I dare name no other man but he,
or should I nominate another prince,
Upon the contrary I may be thought
A most ingrateful wretch unto my friend;
But private cause must yield to public good;
Therefore methinks it were the fittest course,
To choose the worthiest upon this bench.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: We are all Germans, why should we be yoked
Either by Englishmen or Spaniards?

sp.speaker: Saxo.
sp.l: The Earl of Cornwall by a full consent
Was sent for out of England.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: Though he were,
Our later thoughts are purer than our first,
And to conclude, I think this end were best,
Since we have once chosen him emperor,
That some great prince of wisdom and of power,
Whose countenance may overbear his pride,
Be joined in equal government with Alphonsus.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: Your holiness hath soundly in few words
Set down a mean to quiet all these broils.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.l: So may we hope for peace if he amend;
But shall prince Richard then be joined with him?

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: Why should your highness ask that question?
As if a prince of so high kingly birth,
Would live in couples with so base a cur?

sp.speaker: Bohe.
sp.l: Prince Palatine, such words do ill become thee.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: He said but right, and called dog a dog.

sp.speaker: Bohe.
sp.l: His birth is princely.

sp.speaker: Saxo.
sp.l: His manners villainous,
And virtuous Richard scorns so base a yoke.

sp.speaker: Bohe.
sp.l: My lord of Saxon, give me leave to tell you ▪
Ambition blinds your judgement in this case;
You hope, if by your means Richard be emperor,
He, in requital of so great advancement,
Will make the long-desired marriage up
Between the prince of England and your sister,
And to that end Edward the prince of Wales,
Hath born his uncle company to Germany.

sp.speaker: Saxo.
sp.l: Why King of Bohem is't unknown to thee,
How oft the Saxons sons have married Queens,
And daughter's Kings, yea mightiest emperors?
If Edward like her beauty and behaviour,
He'll make no question of her princely birth;
But let that pass, I say, as erst I said,
That virtuous Richard scorns so base a yoke.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: If Richard scorn, some one upon this bench,
Whose power may overbear Alphonsus' pride,
Is to be named. What think you my lords?

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: I think it was a mighty mass of gold,
That made your grace of this opinion.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: My lord of Saxony, you wrong me much,
And know I highly scorn to take a bribe.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: I think you scorn indeed to have it known:
But to the purpose, if it must be so,
Who is the fittest man to join with him?

sp.speaker: Collen.
sp.l: First with an ox to plough will I be yoked.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: The fittest is your grace in mine opinion.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: I am content, to stay these mutinies,
To take upon me what you do impose.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: Why here's a tempest quickly overblown.
God give you joy my lord of half the empire;
For me I will not meddle in the matter,
But warn your majesty to have a care,
And vigilant respect unto your person,
I'll hie me home to fortify my towns,
Not to offend, but to defend myself.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: Have with you cousin, and adieu my lords,
I am afraid this sudden knitted peace,
Will turn unto a tedious lasting war;
Only thus much we do request you all,
Deal honourably with the Earl of Cornwall,
And so adieu.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: I like not this strange farewell of the Dukes.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: In all elections some are malcontent.
It doth concern us now with speed to know,
How the competitors will like of this,
And therefore you my lord Archbishop of trier,
Impart this order of arbitrament
Unto the emperor ▪ bid him be content,
To stand content with half, or lose the whole.
My lord of Mentz go you unto prince Richard,
and tell him flatly here's no crown, nor empire
For English islanders; tell him, 'twere his best,
To hie him home to help the King his brother,
Against the Earl of Leicester and the barons.

sp.speaker: Collen.
sp.l: My lord of Mentz, sweet words will qualify,
When bitter terms will add unto his rage.
'Tis no small hope that hath deceived the Duke;
Therefore be mild; I know an Englishman,
Being flattered, is a lamb, threatened, a lion;
Tell him his charges what so e'er they are
Shall be repaid with treble vantages;
Do this; we will expect their resolutions.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: Brother of Collen, I entreat your grace
To take this charge upon you in my stead;
For why I shame to look him in the face.

sp.speaker: Collen.
sp.l: Your holiness shall pardon me in this,
Had I the profit I would take the pains;
With shame enough your grace may bring the message.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: Thus am I wronged, God knows, unguiltily.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: Then arm your countenance with innocency,
And boldly do the message to the prince;
For no man else will be the messenger.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: Why then I must, since there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: If heaven that guides the hearts of mighty men ▪
Do calm the winds of these great potentates,
And make them like of this arbitrament,
Sweet peace will triumph through Christendom,
And Germany shall bless this happy day.

div.stage: Enter Alexander de Toledo the page.

sp.speaker: Alexand.
sp.l: O me most miserable o my dear father!

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: What means this passionate accent? what art thou
That sounds these acclamations in our ears?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Pardon me princes, I have lost a father,
Oh me, the name of father kills my heart.
O! I shall never see my father more,
Has ta'en his leave of me for age and age.

sp.speaker: Collen.
sp.l: What was thy father?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Ah me I what was a not?
Noble, rich, valiant, well-beloved of all,
The glory and the wisdom of his age,
Chief secretary to the emperor.

sp.speaker: Collen.
sp.l: Lorenzo de Toledo, is he dead?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Dead, ay me dead, ay me my life is dead,
Strangely this night bereft of breath and sense,
And I, poor I, am comforted in nothing,
But that the emperor laments with me,
As I exclaim, so he, he rings his hands,
And makes me mad to see his majesty
Excruciate himself with endless sorrow.

sp.speaker: Collen.
sp.l: The happiest news that ever I did hear;
Thy father was a villain murderer,
Witty, not wise, loved like a scorpion,
Grown rich by the impoverishing of others,
The chiefest cause of all these mutinies,
And Caesar's tutor to all villainy.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: None but an open liar terms him so.

sp.speaker: Col.
sp.l: What boy, so malepert?

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: Good Collen bear with him, it was his father,
Dutch-land is blessed in Lorenzo's death.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: Did never live a viler minded man.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Nor King, nor churfurst should be privileged
To call me boy, and rail upon my father,
Were I wehrsafflig; but in Germany,
A man must be a boy at 40. years,
And dares not draw his weapon at a dog,
Till being soundly boxed about the ears,
His lord and master gird him with a sword;
The time will come I shall be made a man,
Till then I'll pine with thought of dire revenge,
And live in hell until I take revenge.

div.head: Act. ii.
div.stage: Enter Alphonsus, Richard Earl of Cornwall, Mentz, Trier, prince Edward, Bohemia, Collen, Brandenburge, attendants, and pages with a sword.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: Behold here come the prince's hand in hand,
Pleased highly with the sentence as it seems.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Princes and pillars of the monarchy,
We do admire your wisdoms in this cause,
And do accept the King of Bohemia,
As worthy partner in the government.
Alas my lords, I flatly now confess,
I was alone too weak to underprop
So great a burden as the Roman empire,
And hope to make you all admire the course
That we intend in this conjunction.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: That I was called from England with consent
Of all the seven electors to this place,
Yourselves best know, who wrote for me to come.
'Twas no ambition moved me to the journey,
But pity of your half declining state;
Which being likely now to be repaired,
By the united force of these two Kings,
I rest content to see you satisfied.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: Brave Earl, wonder of princely patience,
I hope your grace will not misthink of me,
Who for your good, and for the empire's best,
Bethought this means to set the world at peace.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: No doubt this means might have been thought upon,
Although your holiness had died in prison.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: Peace, peace young prince, you want experience;
Your uncle knows what cares accompany,
And wait upon the crowns of mightiest Kings,
And glad he is that he hath shaked it off.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Hark in your ear my lord, hear me one word,
Although it were more than a million,
Which these two Kings bestowed upon your grace,
Mine uncle Richard's million saved your life.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: You were best to say, your uncle bribed me then.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I do but say mine uncle saved your life,
You know count Mansfield your fellow prisoner,
Was by the Duke of Brunswick put to death.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: You are a child my lord, your words are wind.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: You are a fox my lord, and passed a child.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: My lord of Cornwall, your great forwardness,
Crossing the seas with aid of Englishmen,
Is more than we can any way requite;
But this your admirable patience,
In being pleased with our election,
Deserves far more than thanks can satisfy,
In any thing command the emperors,
Who live to honour Richard Earl of Cornwall.

sp.speaker: Alpho.
sp.l: Our deeds shall make our protestations good,
Meanwhile , brave princes, let us leave this place,
And solace us with joy of this accord.

div.stage: Enter Isabella the empress, Hedewick the Duke of Saxon's daughter, apparelled like fortune, drawn on a globe, with a cup in her hand, wherein are bay leaves, whereupon are written the lots. A train of ladies following with music.

sp.speaker: Empress.
sp.l: To gratulate this unexpected peace,
This glorious league confirmed against all hope,
Joyful Isabella doth present this show,
Of fortune's triumph, as the custom is
At coronation of our emperors;
If therefore every party be well pleased,
And stand content with this arbitrament,
Then deign to do as your progenitors,
And draw in sequence lots for offices.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: This is an order here in Germany,
For princes to disport themselves with all,
In sign their hearts so firmly are conjoined,
That they will bear all fortunes equally,
And that the world may know I scorn no state,
Or course of life to do the empire good,
I take my chance: my fortune is to be the forester,

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: If we want venison either red or fallow,
wild boar or bear, you must be fined my lord.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: The emperor's taster I.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Your majesty hath been tasted to so oft,
That you have need of small instructions.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: I am the bower, sister what is my charge?

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Tired like a carter, and a clownish bower,
To bring a load of wood into the kitchen.
Now for myself, faith I am chamber maid,
I know my charge; proceed unto the next.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Prince Edward standeth melancholy still,
Please it your grace, my lord, to draw your lot.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Nephew you must be solemn with the sad,
And given to mirth in sportful company,
The German princes when they will be lusty,
Shake of all cares, and clowns and they are fellows.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Sweet aunt, I do not know the country guise,
Yet would be glad to learn all fashions.
Since I am next, good fortune be my guide.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: A most ingenuous countenance hath this prince,
Worthy to be the King of England's heir.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Be it no disparagement to you my lords,
I am your emperor.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Sound trumpets, God save the emperor.

sp.speaker: Collen.
sp.l: The world could never worse have fitted me,
I am not old enough to be the cook.

sp.speaker: Empress.
sp.l: If you be cook, there is no remedy
But you must dress one mess of meat you self.

sp.speaker: Branden.
sp.l: I am physician.

sp.speaker: Trier.
sp.l: I am secretary.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: I am the jester.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: O excellent! is your holiness the vice?
Fortune hath fitted you i'faith my lord,
You'll play the Ambodexter cunningly.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: Your highness is too bitter in your jests.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Come hither Alexander, to comfort thee,
After the death of thy beloved father,
Whose life was dear unto his emperor,
Thou shalt make one in this solemnity,
Yet ere thou draw, myself will honour thee,
And as the custom is make thee a man.
Stand stiff sir boy, now comest thou to thy trial;
Take this, and that, and therewithal this sword;
sp.stage: [he gives Alexander a box on the ear or two.
sp.l: If while thou live, thou ever take the like,
Of me, or any man, I here pronounce
Thou art a schelm, otherwise a man.
Now draw thy lot, and fortune be thy speed.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Uncle I pray why did be box the fellow?
Foul lubber as he is, to take such blows.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Thus do the princes make their pages men.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: But that is strange to make a man with blows.
We say in England that he is a man,
That like a man dare meet his enemy,
And in my judgement 'tis the sounder trial.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Fortune hath made me marshal of the triumphs.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Now what remains?

sp.speaker: Emperess.
sp.l: That fortune draw her lot.

div.stage: She opens it, and gives it to the emperess to read.

sp.speaker: Empress.
sp.l: Sound trumpets, fortune is your emperess.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: This happens right: for fortune will be Queen.
Now emperor you must unmask her face,
And tell us how you like your emperess,
In my opinion England breeds no fairer.

sp.speaker: Bohe.
sp.l: Fair Hedewick the Duke of Saxons daughter,
Young prince of England, you are bravely matched.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Tell me sweet aunt, is that this Saxon Princess,
Whose beauties fame made Edward cross the seas?

sp.speaker: Emperess.
sp.l: Nephew, it is; hath fame been prodigal,
Or over sparing in the Princess praise?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Fame I accuse thee, thou didst niggardize,
And faintly sound my love's perfections.
Great lady fortune, and fair emperess,
Whom chance this day hath thrown into my arms,
More welcome than the Roman emperess.

sp.speaker: Hede.
sp.l: See dodh, dass ist hire kein gebranch,
Mein g●t ist dass dir English manier, dass dich.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: What meaneth this? why chafes my emperess?

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Now by my troth, I did expect this jest,
Prince Edward used his country fashion.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I am an Englishman, why should I not?

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Fie nephew Edward, here in Germany
To kiss a maid, a fault intolerable.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Why should not German maids be kissed as well as others?

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Nephew, because you did not know the fashion,
And want the language to excuse your self,
I'll be your spokesman to your emperess.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Excuse it thus: I like the first so well,
That tell her, she shall chide me twice as much
For such another; nay tell her more than so,
I'll double kiss on kiss, and give her leave
To chide and brawl, and cry ten thousand dass dich,
And make her weary of her fretting humour,
Ere I be weary of my kissing vein,
Dass dich a jungfraw angry for a kiss.

sp.speaker: Empress.
sp.l: Nephew, she thinks you mock her in her mirth.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I think the princes make a scorn of me.
If any do, I'll prove it with my sword,
That English courtship leaves it from the world.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: The pleasantest accident that I have seen.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Methinks the prince is chafed as well as she.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Gnediges frawlin.

sp.speaker: Hede.
sp.p: Dass dich, m●stich arm kindt ●n schanden 〈◊〉 werden.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Dass dich I have kissed as good as you,
Pray uncle tell her; if she mislike the kiss,
I'll take it off again with such another.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Ey lirbes frawlin nim es all fur gutt●
Es is't die English manier und gebrauche.

sp.speaker: Hede.
sp.p: Ewer gnaden weissts will es ist mir ein gross schande.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Good aunt teach me so much Dutch to ask her pardon.

sp.speaker: Empress.
sp.l: Say so: gnediges frawlin vergebet mirs, ich wills nimmermehr thuen,
Then kiss your hand three times upsy Dutch.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Ich wills 〈◊〉 thuen, if I understand it, right,
That's as much to say, as I'll do so no more.

sp.speaker: Empr.
sp.l: True nephew.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Nay aunt pardon me I pray, I hope to kiss her many thousand times,
And shall I go to her like a great boy, and say I'll do so no more.

sp.speaker: Empress.
sp.l: I pray cousin say as I tell you.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Gnediges frawlin vergebet mirss ich wills nimmermehr thuen.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: For wahr kein schandt.

sp.speaker: Hedew.
sp.l: Gnediger hochgeborner furst undt herr
Wan ich konte so vil English sprechen ich wolt ewer gnaden.
Fur wahr ein filtz geben, ich hoffe aber ich soll e●●mahl
So viel lernen dass die mich verstrhen soll.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: What says she?

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: O excellent young prince look to yourself,
She swears she'll learn some English for your sake,
To make you understand her when she chides.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I'll teach her English, she shall teach me Dutch, gnediges frawlin, etc.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: It is great pity that the Duke of Saxon,
Is absent at this joyful accident,
I see no reason if his grace were here,
But that the marriage might be solemnised,
I think the prince of Wales were well content.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I left sweet England to none other end;
And though the prince her father be not here,
This royal presence knows his mind in this.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Since you do come so roundly to the purpose,
'Tis time for me to speak, the maid is mine,
Given freely by her father unto me,
And to the end these broils may have an end,
I give the father's interest and mine own,
Unto my nephew Edward prince of Wales.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: A jewel of incomparable price,
Your majesty hath here bestowed on me,
How shall I ask her if she be content?

sp.speaker: Empr.
sp.l: Say thus, is't ewer gnaden will hiemit zufrieden.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Is't ewer gnaden will hiemit zufrieden.

sp.speaker: Hede.
sp.l: Wass ihr durleichtigkeit dass will dass will mein vattter undt
Wass mein vatter will darmit muss ich zufrieden sein.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: It is enough, she doth confirm the match;
we will dispatch a post unto her father,
On Sunday shall the revels and the wedding,
Be both solemnised with mutual joy.
Sound trumpets, each one look unto his charge,
For preparation of the festivals.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Come hither Alexander, thy father's joy.
If tears and sighs, and deep-fetched deadly groans,
Could serve to evert inexorable fate,
Divine Lorenzo, whom in life my heart,
In death my soul and better part adores,
Had to thy comfort and his prince's honour,
Survived, and drawn this day this breath of life.

sp.speaker: Alexan.
sp.l: Dread Caesar, prostrate on my bent knee,
I thank your majesty for all favours shown
To my deceased father and myself.
I must confess, I spend but bootless tears,
Yet cannot bridle nature, I must weep,
Or heart will break with burden of my thoughts,
Nor am I yet so young or fond withal,
Causeless to spend my gall, and fret my heart,
'Tis not that he is dead, for all must die;
But that I live to hear his life's reproach.
O sacred emperor, these ears have heard,
What no sons ears can unrevenged hear,
The princes all of them, but specially,
The prince elector Archbishop of Collen,
Reviled him by the names of murderer,
Arch villain, robber of the empire's fame,
And Caesar's tutor in all wickedness,
And with a general voice applaused his death,
As for a special good to Christendom.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Have they not reason to applaud the deed
Which they themselves have plotted? ah my boy,
Thou art too young to dive into their drifts.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Yet old enough I hope to be revenged.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: What wilt thou do, or whither wilt thou run?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Headlong ▪ to bring them ▪ death, then die myself.

sp.speaker: Alph●n.
sp.l: First hear the reason why I do mistrust them.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: They had no reason for my father's death,
And I scorn reason till they all be dead.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Thou wilt not scorn my counsel in revenge?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: My rage admits no counsel but revenge.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: First let me tell thee whom I do mistrust.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Your highness said you did mistrust them all.

sp.speaker: Alpho.
sp.l: Yea Alexander, all of them, and more than all,
〈◊〉 most especial nearest dearest friends.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: All is one to me, for know thou emperor,
Were it thy father, brother, or thine empress,
Yea were 't thyself, that didst conspire his death,
This fatal hand should take away thy life.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Spoken like a son, worthy so dear a father.
Be still and hearken, I will tell thee all,
The Duke of Saxon —

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O, I thought no less.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Suppress thy choler, harken to the rest.
Saxon I say so wrought with flattering Mentz,
Mentz with Bohemia, trier, and Brandenburg,
For Collen and the Palsgrave of the Rhein
Were principals with Saxon in the plot,
That in a general meeting to that purpose,
The seven selected emperors electors,
Most heinously concluded of the murder;
The reason why they doomed him unto death,
Was his deep wisdom and sound policy;
Knowing while he did live my state was firm,
He being dead my hope must die with him.
Now Alexander will we be revenged
Upon this wicked whore of Babylon,
This hideous monster with the sevenfold head:
We must with cunning level at the heart,
With pierced and perished all the body dies:
Or strike we off her heads by one and one,
Behooveth us to use dexterity,
Lest she do trample us under her feet,
And triumph in our honours overthrow.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Mad and amaze to hear this tragic doom,
I do subscribe unto your sound advice.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Then hear the rest; these seven dave but 〈◊〉 ten
a nearer hand put it in execution,
And but I loved Lorenzo as my life,
I never would betray my dearest wife.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: What? what the empress accessary to?

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: What cannot kindred do? her brother Richard,
Hoping thereby to be an emperor,
Gave her a dram that sent him to his grave.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O my poor father, wert thou such an eyesore,
That 9. the greatest princes of the earth
Must be confederate in thy tragedy?
But why do I respect their mightiness,
Who did not once respect my father's life?
Your majesty may take it as you please,
I'll be revenged upon your emperess,
On English Richard, Saxon, and the Palsgrave,
On Bohem, Collen, Mentz, trier, and Brandenburg,
If that the Pope of Rome himself were one
In this confederacy, undaunted I.
Amid the college of his Cardinals,
Would press, and stab him in st. Peter's chair,
Though clad in all his pontificalibus.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Why Alexander? dost thou speak to me
As if thou didst mistrust my forwardness?
No, thou shalt know my love to him was such,
And in my heart I have proscribed them all,
That had to do in this conspiracy.
The bands of wedlock shall not serve her turn,
Her fatal lot is cast among the rest,
And to conclude, my soul doth live in hell
Till I have set my foot upon their necks,
That gave this spur of sorrow to my heart;
But with advice it must be managed,
Not with a headlong rage as thou intendest,
Nor in a moment can it be performed,
This work requires long time, dissembling looks,
Commixed with undermining actions,
Watching advantages to execute.
Our foes are mighty, and their number great,
It therefore follows that our stratagems
Must branch forth into manifold deceits,
endless devices, bottomless conclusions.

sp.speaker: Alexan.
sp.l: What by your majesty is prescribed to me,
That will I execute or die the death.
I am content to suck my sorrows up,
And with dull patience will attend the time,
Gaping for every opportunity
That may present the least occasion;
Although each minute multiply mine anguish,
And to my view present a thousand forms
Of senseless bodies in my father's shape,
Yelling with open throat for just revenge.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Content thyself, he shall not cry in vain,
I have already plotted Richard's death.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: That hath my father's sacred ghost inspired,
Oh tell me, shall I stab him suddenly?
The time seems long, till I be set a work.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Thou knowest in griping at our lots today,
It was prince Richard's hap to be the bower;
So that his office is to drive the cart,
And bring a load of wood into the kitchen.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O excellent, your grace being forester,
As in the thicket he doth load the cart,
May shoot him dead, as if he were a deer.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: No Alexander, that device were shallow,
Thus it must be, there are two very hours
Appointed for to help him in the wood,
These must be bribed or cunningly seduced,
Instead of helping him to murder him.

sp.speaker: Ale.
sp.l: Verbum satis sapienti, it is enough,
Fortune hath made me marshal of the sports
I hope to marshal them to th' devil's feast.
Plot you the rest, this will I execute,
Dutch bowers as thousand schelms and gold to tempt them.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: 'Tis right, about it then, but cunningly.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Else let me lose that good opinion
Which by your highness I desire to hold,
By letters which I'll strew within the wood,
I'll undermine the bowers to murder him,
Nor shall they know who set them so a work,
Like a familiar will I fly about,
and nimbly haunt their ghosts in every nook.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: This one nail helps to drive the other out,
I slew the father, and bewitch the son,
With power of words to be the instrument
To rid my foes with danger of his life.
How easily can subtle age entice,
Such credulous young novices to their death?
Huge wonders will Alphonsus bring to pass,
By the mad mind of this enraged boy;
Even they which think themselves my greatest friends,
Shall fall by this deceit, yea my arch-enemies
Shall turn to be my chief confederates.
My solitary walks may breed suspect,
I'll therefore give myself to company,
As I intended nothing out these sports,
Yet hope to send most actors in this pageant,
To revel it with Rhadamant in hell.

div.stage: Enter Richard Earl of Cornwall like a clown.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: How far is Richard now unlike the man
The crossed the seas to win an empery?
But as I plod it like a plumper bower,
To fetch in fuel for the kitchen fire,
So every one in his vocation,
Labours to make the pastimes plausible;
My nephew Edward jets it through the court,
With Princess Hedewick empress of his fortune,
The demi Caesar in his hunter's suit,
Makes all the court to ring with horns and hounds,
Collen the cook bestirs him in the kitchen;
But that which joys me most in all these sports,
Is Mentz, to see how he is made an ass?
The common scorn and byword of the court;
And every one to be the same he seems,
Seems to forget to be the same he is.
Yet to my robes I cannot suit my mind,
Nor with my habit shake dishonour off ▪
The seven electors promised me the empire,
The perjured Bishop Mentz did swear no less,
yet I have seen it shared before my face,
While my best friends do hide their heads for shame;
I bear a show of outward full content,
But grief thereof hath almost killed my heart.
Here rest thee Richard, think upon a mean,
To end thy life, or to repair thine honour,
And vow never to see fair England's bounds,
Till thou in Aix be crowned emperor.
Holla, methinks there cometh company,
The bowers I trow that come to hew the wood,
Which I must carry to the kitchen fire,
I'll lie a while and listen to their talk.

div.stage: Enter Hans and Jerick two Dutch bowers.

sp.speaker: Je.
sp.p: Kom hire hans wore bist dow, warumb bist dow so trawrick? biss frolick kan well gelt verdienen, wir wil● ihn bey pots tawsandt todt schlagen.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Lat mich die brief sehen.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: methinks they talk of murdering somebody , I'll listen more.
Hans und Jerick, mein liebe friend, ich bit lasset es bey euch bleiben in geheim, und schlaget den engellander zu todt.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: What's that? Hans und Jerick my good friend, I pray be secret and murder the Englishman.
Hear weiter, den er ist kein bower night, er ist ein juncker, und hatt viel gelt und kleinothen bey sich.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: For he is no bower but a gentleman, and hath store of gold and jewels by him.

sp.speaker: ●eric.
sp.p: Noch weiter: ihr solt solche gelegenheit night versahmen ▪ und 〈◊〉 ihr gethan habet, ich will euch sagen, was ich fur ein guter rarl been der euch raht gegeben habe.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Skip not this opportunity, and when you have done, I will discover who gave you the counsel.

sp.speaker: Jerick.
sp.p: Wat sagst dow wilt dow es thun?

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Wat will ich nich fur gelt thun? see pots tausendt, dar is't er.

sp.speaker: Jerick.
sp.p: Ja, bey pots tausends slapperment, er ists, holla guter morgen, gluck zu juncker.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Juncker, daer devil he is ein bower!

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Dow bist ein schelm, weich von mir.

sp.speaker: Jerick.
sp.p: Holla, holla, bist dow so hoffertick? Juncker bower, kompt hire, oder dieser und jenner selleuch holen.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Ich bien ein furst, bried mich night ihr schelms, ihr verrahters.

sp.speaker: Bath.
sp.p: Sla to, fla to, wir will ye furstlick tractieren.
Richard having nothing in his hand but his whip, defends himself a while, and then falls down ▪ as if he were dead:

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: O got, nimb meine seele in deine haude.

sp.speaker: Jerick.
sp.p: O excellent, hurtick he is todt, he is todt.
Lat uns see what he hat for gelt bey sich, holla hire is all enough all sat, dor is for dich, and dor is for mich, und ditt 〈…〉:

div.stage: Jerick puts the chain about his neck.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: How so hans narhals, give mir die kette hire.

sp.speaker: Jerick.
sp.p: Ja ein dreck, dit kett stehet hupsch umb mein hals, ditt will ich tragen.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Dat dich pots velten leiden, dat soltu nimmermehr thu● dow schelm.

sp.speaker: Jerick.
sp.p: Wat solt dow mich schelm heiten nimb dat.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Dat dich hundert tonnen devils, harr ich will dich 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Jerick.
sp.p: Wiltud hawen oder stechen?

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Ich will redlich hawen;

sp.speaker: Jerick.
sp.p: Nun wollan, dor is't mein ruck, sla to.

div.stage: They must have axes made for the nonst to fight withal, and while one strikes, the other holds his back without defence.

sp.speaker: Hans.
sp.p: Nimb dow das, und dar hast mein ruck.

sp.speaker: J●rick.
sp.p: Nach amahl: oh excellent, ligst dow dar, nun will ich alles haben, gelt und kett, und all mit einander, oh hurtig, frisch-up lustig, nun been ich ein hurtig juncker.

div.stage: Richard rises up again and 〈◊〉 up the fellows hatchet that was slain.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: Nè Hercules contra dvos, yet policy hath gone beyond them both.
Du hudler schelm, morder, kehre dich, feestu mich? gebe mir die kett und gelt wieder;

sp.speaker: Jerick.
sp.p: Wat bistu wieder labendig word, so mus ich meren, wat wiltu stechen oder hawen?

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.p: So will ich machen du schelm ▪

sp.speaker: Jerick.
sp.p: Harr, harr, bistu ein redlich karle, so fight redlich, oh ich sterb, ich sterb, lat mich leben!

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.p: Sagt mir dan waer hatt die brief geschrieben?
Lie night sondern sagt die warheit:

sp.speaker: Jerick.
sp.p: O mein fromer, guter, edler, gestrenger juncker, dar is't dat gelt und kett wieder, ye soll alles haben, aber waer hatt die brief geschrieben, dat wet ich bey meiner seele night.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Lig dor still, still ich sag.
The villain swears, and deeply doth protest
He knows not who incited them to this,
And as it seems the scroll imports no less.
So sterb du mir schelm.

sp.speaker: Jerick.
sp.p: O ich sterb, awe, awe, awe dat dich daer divell hole!

div.stage: As Richard kills the bower. Enter Saxon and the Palsgrave.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.p: Fie dich an loser schelm, hastu dein gesellen todt geschlagen?

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.p: Last us den schelmen angreiffen.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Call you me shelme how dare you then
Being prince's offer to lay hands on me?
That is the hangman's office here in Dutch-land.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: But this is strange, our bours can speak no English,
What bistum more than a damned murderer?
That thou art so much we are witnesses.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Can then this habit alter me so much,
That I am called a villain by my friends?
Or shall I dare once to suspect your graces,
That for you could not make me emperor,
Pitying my sorrow through mine honour lost,
You set these slaves to rid me of my life,
Yet far be such a thought from Richard's heart.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: How now? what do I hear prince Richard speak?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: The same: but wonder that he lives to speak.
And had not policy helped above strength,
These sturdy swains had rid me of my life.

sp.speaker: Sax.
sp.l: Far be it from your grace for to suspect us.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Alas, I know not whom I should suspect;
But yet my heart cannot misdoubt your graces?

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: How came your highness into this apparel?

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: We as the manner is drawn lots for offices,
My hap was hardest to be made a carter,
And by this letter which some villain wrote,
I was betrayed, here to be murdered;
But heaven which doth defend the innocent,
Armed me with strength and policy together,
That I escaped out of their treacherous snare.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: Were it well sounded, I dare lay my life,
The Spanish tyrant knew of this conspiracy;
Therefore the better to dive into the depth
Of this most devilish murderous complot,
As also secretly to be beholders,
Of the long-wished for wedding of your daughter,
We will disrobe these bowers of their apparel,
Clapping their rustic cases on our backs,
And help your highness for to drive the cart.
It may be the traitor that did write these lines,
Mistaking us for them will show himself.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Prince Palatine this plot doth please me well,
I make no doubt if we deal cunningly,
But we shall find the writer of this scroll.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: And in that hope I will disrobe this slave.
Come princes in the neighbouring thicket here,
We may disguise ourselves, and talk at pleasure;
Fie on him heavy lubber how he weighs.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: The sin of murder hangs upon his soul,
It is no marvel then if he be heavy.

div.head: Act. iii.
div.stage: Edward with an imperial crown. Hedewig the empress. Bohemia the taster. Alphonsus the forester. Mentz the gester. Empress the chambermaid. Brandenburg physician. Tryer secretary. Alexander the marshal, with his marshals staff, and all the rest in their proper apparel, and attendants and pages.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Princes and prince's superiors, lords and lords fellows, gentlemen and gentlemen's masters, and all the rest of the states here assembled, as well masculine as feminine, be it known unto you by these presence, that I Alexander de Toledo, fortune's chief marshal, do will and command you, by the authority of my said office, to take your places in manner and form following, first the emperor and the empress, than the taster, the secretary, the forester, the physician, as for the chambermaid and myself, we will take our places at the neither end, the jester is to wait up, and live by the crumbs that fall from the emperor's trencher, but now I have marshaled you to the table, what remains?

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p: Every fool can tell that, when men are set to dinner they commonly expect meat.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: That's the best jest the fool made since he came into his office. Marshal walk into the kitchen, and see how the churfurst of Collen bestirs himself.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p: Shall I go with him too? I love to be employed in the kitchen.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: I prithee go, that we may be rid of thy wicked jests.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.p: Have with thee marshal, the fool rides thee?

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.p: Now by mine honour, my lord of Mentz plays the fool the worst that ever I saw.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: He does all by contraries; for I am sure he played the wiseman like a fool, and now he plays the fool wisely.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Princes and churfursts let us frolic now,
This is a joyful day to Christendom,
When Christian princes join in amity,
Schinck bowls of reinfal and the purest wine,
We'll spend this evening lusty upsy Dutch,
In honour of this unexpected league.

sp.speaker: Empres.
sp.l: Nay gentle forester, there you range amiss,
His looks are fitly suited to his thoughts.
His glorious empress makes his heart triumph,
And hearts triumphing makes his countenance stayed ▪
In contemplation of his lives delight.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Good aunt let me excuse myself in this,
I and an emperor but for a day,
She empress of my heart while life doth last;
Then give me leave to use imperial looks.
Nay if I be an emperor I'll take leave,
And here I do pronounce it openly,
What I have lately whispered in her ears,
I love mine empress more than empery,
I love her looks above my fortune's hope.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Saving your looks dread emperor es gelt a bowl,
Unto the health of your fair bride and empress.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Sain got es soll mir en liebe drunk sein, so much Dutch have I learned since I came into Germany.

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: When you have drunk a dozen of these bowls,
So can your majesty with a full mouth,
Trowel out high Dutch, till then it sounds not right ▪
Darauff es gelt noch eins thr maiestat.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Sain got lass lauffen.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: My lord of Brandenburg spoken like a good Dutch brother;
But most unlike a good physician,
You should consider what he has to do,
His bride will give you little thanks tonight .

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Ha, ha my lord, now give me leave to laugh,
He need not therefore shun one beaker full.
In Saxon land you know it is the use,
That the first night the bridegroom spares the bride.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: 'Tis true indeed, that had I quite forgotten.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: How understand I that?

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: That the first night,
The bride and bridegroom never sleep together.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: That may well be, perchance they wake together.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: Nay without fallace they have several beds.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I in one chamber, that is most princely.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Not only several beds, but several chambers,
Locked soundly too, with iron bolts and bars.

sp.speaker: Empr.
sp.l: Believe me nephew, that's the custom here.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: O my good aunt, the world is now grown new,
Old customs are but superstitions.
I 'em sure this day, this presence all can witness,
The high and mighty prince th' Archbishop of Collen,
Who now is busy in the scullery,
Joined us together in st. Peter's church,
And he that would disjoin us two tonight ,
Betwixt jest and earnest be it proudly spoken,
Shall eat a piece of ill-digesting iron.
Bride wilt dow dis night ben me schlapen.

sp.speaker: Hede.
sp.p: Da behute mich gott fur, ich hoffe eure 〈◊〉 wills von mir mi●t, begeran.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: What says she behuie mich got fur?

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: She says God bless her from such a deed.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Tush empress, clap thy hands upon thy head,
And God will bless thee, I have a Jacob's staff,
Shall take the elevation of the pole;
For I have heard it said, the Dutch North star,
Is a degree or two higher than ours.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: Nay though we talk let's drink, and emperor,
I'll tell you plainly what you must trust unto,
Can they deceive you of your bride tonight ,
They'll surely do't, therefore look to yourself.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: If she deceive me not, let all do their worst.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Assure you emperor she'll do her best.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I think the maids in Germany are mad,
Ere they be married they will not kiss,
And being married will not go to bed.
We drink about, let's talk no more of this,
Well warned half armed our English proverb say

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Holla marshal, what says the cook?
Belike he thinks we have fed so well already,
That we disdain his simple cookery.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Faith the gook says so, that his office was to dress a mess of meat with that wood which the English prince should bring in, but he hath neither seen Dutch wood nor English prince, therefore he desires you hold him excused.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: I wonder where prince Richard stays so long.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: An't, please your majesty, he's come at length,
And with him has he brought a crew of bowers,
A hipse bower maikins fresh as flowers in may,
With whom they mean to dance a Saxon round,
In honour of the bridegroom and his bride.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: So has he made amends for his long tarrying.
I prithee marshal them into the presence.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.p: Lives Richard then? I had thought th' hadst made him sure.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: O, I could tear my flesh to think upon 't,
He lives and secretly hath brought with him,
The Palsgrave and the Duke of Saxony,
Clad like two bowers, even in the same apparel
That Hans and Jerick wore when they went out to murder him,
It now behooves us to be circumspect.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: It likes me not; away marshal bring them.
I long to see this sport's conclusion.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: Is't not a lovely sight to see this couple
Sit sweetly billing like two turtle doves.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: I promise you it sets my teeth an edge,
That I must take mine empress in mine arms.
Come hither Isabel, though thy robes be homely,
Thy face and countenance holds colour still.

div.stage: Enter Alexander, Collen, Mentz, Richard, Saxony, Palsgrave, Collen cook, with a gamon of raw bacon, and links or puddings in a platter, Richard, Palsgrave, Saxon, Mentz, like clowns with each of them a mitre with 〈◊〉 on their 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Collen.
sp.l: Dread emperor and empress for today,
I your appointed cook until tomorrow,
Have by the marshal sent my just excuse,
And hope your highness is therewith content,
Our carter here for whom I now do speak,
Says that his axletree broke by the way,
That is his answer, and for you shall not famish,
He and his fellow bowers of the next dorp,
Have brought a schinkel of good raw bacon,
And that's a common meat with us, unsod,
Desiring you, you would not scorn the fare,
'Twil make a cup of wine taste nippitate.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.p: Welcome good fellows, we thank you for your present.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: So spell fresh up and let us rommer daun●e●.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Please it your highness to dance with your bride?

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Alas I cannot dance your German dances.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: I do beseech your highness mock us not,
We Germans have no changes in our dances,
An almain and an upspring that is all,
So dance the princes, burghers, and the bowers.

sp.speaker: Brand.
sp.l: So danced our ancestors for thousand years.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: It is a sign the Dutch are not new fangled.
I'll follow in the measure; marshal lead.
sp.stage: Alexander and Mentz have the fore dance with each of them a glass of wine in their hands, then Edward and Hedewick ▪ Palsgrave and empress, and two other couple, after drum and trumpet.
The Palsgrave whispers with the empress.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: I think the bower is amorous of my empress.
Fort bower and leffel morgen, when thou comest to house.

sp.speaker: Collen.
sp.l: Now is your grace's time to steal away,
look to't or else you'll lie alone tonight .

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: (Drinketh to the Palsgrave.) Skelt bower.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave.
sp.l: Sain gott.
Ey jungfraw help mich doch ein jungfraw drunck
〈◊〉 fcenudt ein frolecken drink.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Sam g●●t mein frundt ich will gern bescheidt thun
sp.stage: (Alphonsus takes the cup of the Palsgrave, and drinks to the King of Bohemia, and after he hath drunk puts poison into the beaker.)
sp.l: Half this I drink unto your highness' health,
It is the first since we were joined in office.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: I thank your majesty, I'll pledge you half.

div.stage: (As Bohem is a drinking, ere he hath drunk it all out, Alphonsus pulls the beaker from his mouth.)

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Hold, hold, your majesty, drink not too much.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: What means your highness.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Methinks that something grates between my teeth,
Pray God there be not poison in the bowl.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: Marry God forbid.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: So were I peppered.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: I highly do mistrust this schelmish bower,
Lay hands on him I le make him drink the rest.
Whas ist whas ist wat will you nut me machen

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Drink out, drink out oder daer divell soll dich holen.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: Ey geb you to frieden ich will gein drink.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: Drink not prince Palatine, throw it on the ground,
It is not good to trust his Spanish flies.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: Saxon and Palsgrave, this cannot be good.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: 'Twas not for naught my mind misgave me so;
This hath prince Richard done t'entrap our lives.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: No Alphonsus, I disdain to be a traitor.

sp.speaker: Empress.
sp.p: O sheath your swords, forbear these needless broils.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Away, I do mistrust thee as the rest.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: Lords hear me speak, to pacify these broils;
For my part I feel no distemperature,
How do you feel yourself?

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.p: I cannot tell, not ill, and yet methinks I am not well.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: Were it a poison 'twould begin to work.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Not so, all poisons do not work alike.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: If there were poison in, which God forbid,
The empress and myself and Alexander,
Have cause to fear as well as any other.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Why didst thou throw the wine upon the earth?
Hadst thou but drunk, thou hadst satisfied our 〈◊〉.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: I will not be enforced by Spanish hands.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: If all be well with us that 'scuse shall serve,
If not, the Spaniards blood will be revenged.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Your majesty is more afraid than hurt.

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: For me I do not fear myself a whit,
Let all be friends, and forward with our mirth.

div.stage: Enter Edward in his nightgown and his shirt.

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: Nephew, how now? is all well with you?

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: I lay my life the prince has lost his bride.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I hope not so, she is but strayed a little.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Your grace must not be angry though we laugh.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: If it had happened by default of mine,
You might have worthily laughed me to scorn;
But to be so deceived, so over reached,
Even as I meant to clasp her in mine arms,
The grief is intolerable, not to be guessed,
Or comprehended by the thought of any,
But by a man that hath been so deceived,
And that's by no man living but myself.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: My princely son-in-law God give you joy.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Of what my princely father?

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: On my daughter.
Your new betroathed wife and bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: I thank you father, indeed I must confess
She is my wife, but not my bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: How so young prince? I saw you steal her hence,
And as methought she went full willingly.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: 'Tis true, I stole her finely from amongst you,
And by the Archbishop of Collen's help,
Got her alone into the bride-chamber,
Where having locked the door, thought all was well.
I could not speak but pointed to the bed,
she answered ja and 'gan for to unlace her;
I seeing that suspected no deceit,
But straight untrust my points, uncased myself,
And in a moment slipped between the sheets;
There lying in deep contemplation,
The Princess of herself drew near to me,
Gave me her hand, spoke prettily in Dutch
I know not what, and kissed me lovingly,
And as I shrank out of my luke warm place
To make her room, she clapped thrice with her feet,
And through a trap-door sunk out of my sight;
Knew I but her confederates in the deed —
I say no more.

sp.speaker: Empress.
sp.l: Tush cousin, be content;
So many lands, so many fashions,
It is the German use, be not impatient,
She will be so much welcomer tomorrow.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: Come nephew, we'll be bedfellows tonight .

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: Nay if I find her not, I'll lie alone,
I have good hope to ferret out her bed,
And so good night sweet Princess all at once.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Goodnight to all; marshal discharge the train.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: To bed, to bed the marshal cries 'tis time.

div.stage: Flourish cornets, manent Saxon, Richard, Palsgrave, Collen, empress.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: Now princes it is time that we advise,
Now we are all fast in the fowler's gin,
Not to escape his subtle snares alive,
Unless by force we break the nets asunder.
When he begins to cavil and pick quarrels,
I will not trust him in the least degree.

sp.speaker: Empress.
sp.l: It may beseem me evil to mistrust
My lord and emperor of so foul a fact;
But love unto his honour and your lives,
Makes me with tears entreat your excellencies
To fly with speed out of his dangerous reach,
His cloudy brow foretells a sudden storm
Of blood not natural but prodigious.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.l: The castle gates are shut, how should we fly;
but were they open, I would lose my life,
Ere I would leave my nephew to the slaughter;
He and his bride were sure to bear the brunt.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: Could I get out of doors, I'd venture that,
And yet I hold their persons dear enough,
I would not doubt, but e'er the morning sun
Should half way run his course into the South ▪
To compass and begird him in his fort,
With Saxon lance-knight and brunt-bearing Switzers,
Who lie in ambuscado not far hence,
That he should come to composition,
And with safe conduct bring into our tents,
Both bride and bridegroom, and all other friends.

sp.speaker: Empress.
sp.l: My chamber window stands upon the wall,
And thence with ease you may escape away.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: Prince Richard, you will bear me company?

sp.speaker: Richard.
sp.l: I will my lord.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: And you prince Palatine?

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: The Spanish tyrant hath me in suspect
Of poisoning him, I'll therefore stay it out,
To fly upon't were to accuse myself.

sp.speaker: Empress.
sp.l: If need require, I'll hide the Palatine,
Until tomorrow, if you stay no longer.

sp.speaker: Saxon.
sp.l: If God be with us, ere tomorrow noon,
We'll be with ensigns spread before the walls,
We leave dear pledges of our quick return.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: May the heavens prosper your just intents.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: This dangerous plot was happily overheard,
Here didst thou listen in a blessed hour.
Alexander, where dost thou hide thyself?
I've sought thee in each corner of the court,
And now or never must thou play the man.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: And now or never must your highness stir,
Treason hath round encompassed your life.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: I have no leisure now to hear thy talk.
Seest thou this key?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.p: Intends your majesty that I should steal into the prince's chambers,
sp.l: And sleeping stab them in their beds tonight ?
That cannot be.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Wilt thou not hear me speak?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: The prince of England, Saxon, and of Collen,
Are in the empress chamber privily.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: All this is nothing, they would murder me,
〈◊〉 not there tonight ; seest thou this key?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: They mean to fly out at the chamber window,
And raise an army to besiege your grace ▪
Now may your highness take them with the deed.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: The prince of Wales I hope is none of them.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Him and his bride by force they will recover.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: What makes the cursed Palsgrave of the Rhein?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Him hath the empress taken to her charge,
And in her closet means to hide him safe.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: To hide him in her closet? of bold deeds,
The dearest charge that e'er she undertook,
Well let them bring their complots to an end,
I'll undermine to meet them in their works,

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Will not your grace surprise them ere they fly?

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: No, let them bring their purpose to effect,
I'll fall upon them at my best advantage,
Seest thou this key? there take it Alexander;
Yet take it not unless thou be resolved ▪
Tush I am fond to make a doubt of thee;
Take it I say, it doth command all doors,
And will make open way to dire revenge.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: I know not what your majesty doth mean ▪

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Hie thee with speed into the inner chamber,
Next to the chap, and there shalt thou find
The dainty trembling bride couched in her bed,
Having beguiled her bridegroom of his hopes,
Taking her farewell of virginity,
Which she tomorrow night expects to lose,
By night all cats are grey, and in the dark,
She will embrace thee for the prince of Wales,
Thinking that he hath found her chamber out,
Fall to thy business and make few words,
And having pleased thy senses with delight,
and filled thy beating veins with stealing joy,
Make thence again before the break of day,
What strange events will follow this device,
We need not study on, our foes shall find.
How now? how standst thou? hast thou not the heart?

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Should I not have the heart to do this deed,
I were a bastard villain and no man;
Her sweetness, and the sweetness of revenge,
Tickles my senses in a double sense,
And so I wish your majesty good night.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: God night, sweet Venus prosper thy attempt.

sp.speaker: Alex.
sp.l: Sweet Venus and grim Ate I implore,
Stand both of you to me auspicious.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: It had been pity of his father's life,
Whose death hath made him such a perfect villain.
What murder, wrack, and causeless enmity,
Betwixt dearest friends that are my strongest foes,
Will follow suddenly upon this rape,
I hope to live to see, and laugh thereat,
And yet this piece of practice is not all.
The King of Bohem though he little feel it,
Because in twenty hours it will not work,
Hath from my knife's point sucked his deadly bane,
Whereof I will be least of all suspected;
For I will feign myself as sick as he,
And blind mine enemies' eyes with deadly groans;
Upon the Palsgrave and mine emperess,
Heavy suspect shall light to bruise their bones;
Though Saxon would not suffer him to taste,
The deadly potion provided for him ▪
He cannot save him from the sword of justice,
When all the world shall think that like a villain,
He hath poisoned two great emperors with one draught;
That deed is done, and by this time I hope,
The other is a doing, Alexander
I doubt it not will do it thoroughly.
While these things are a brewing I'll not sleep,
But suddenly break open the chamber doors,
And rush upon my empress and the Palsgrave,
holla where's the captain of the guard?

sp.speaker: Captain
sp.l: What would your majesty?

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Take six travants well armed and follow,

div.stage: They break with violence into 〈◊〉 chamber, and Alphonsu trayls the empress by the hair.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Come forth thou damned witch, adulteror whore,
Foul scandal to thy name, thy sex, thy blood.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: O emperor, gentle husband, pity me.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Canst thou deny thou wert confederate,
With my arch enemies that sought my blood?
And like a strumpet through thy chamber window,
Hast with thine own hands helped to let them down,
With an intent that they should gather arms,
Besiege my court, and take away my life?

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Ah my Alphonsus.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Thy Alphonsus' whore?

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: O pierce my heart, trail me not by my hair;
What I have done, I did it for the best.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: So for the best advantage of thy lust,
Hast thou in secret Clytaemnestra like,
Hid thy Aegisthus thy adulterous love.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Heaven be the record 'twixt my lord and me,
How pure and sacred I do hold thy bed.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Art thou so impudent to bely the deed,
Is not the Palsgrave hidden in thy chamber?

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: That I have hid the Palsgrave I confess;
But to no ill intent your conscience knows.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Thy treasons, murders, incests, sorceries,
Are all committed to a good intent;
Thou knowest he was my deadly enemy.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: By this device I hoped to make your friends.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Then bring him forth, we'll reconcile ourselves.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Should I betray so great a prince's life?

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Thou holdest his life far dearer than thy lords,
This very night hast thou betrayed my blood,
but thus, and thus, will I revenge myself,
And but thou speedily deliver him,
I'll trail thee through the kennels of the street,
And cut the nose from thy bewitching face,
And into England send thee like a strumpet.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Pull every hair from off my head,
Drag me at horses tails, cut off my nose
My princely tongue shall not betray a prince.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: That will I try.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: O heaven revenge my shame.

sp.speaker: Palsgrave
sp.l: Is Caesar now become a torturer,
A hangman of his wife, turned murderer?
Here is the palatine, what wouldst thou more?

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Upon him soldiers, strike him to the ground.

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: Ah soldiers, spare the princely Palatine.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Down with the damned adulterous murderer,
Kill him I say, his blood be on my head.
Run to the tower, and ring the alarm bell,
That fore the world I may excuse myself,
And tell the reason of this bloody deed.

div.stage: Enter Edward in his night gown and shirt.

sp.speaker: Edw.
sp.l: How now? what means this sudden strange alarm?
What wretched dame is this with blubbered cheeks,
And rent dishevelled hair?

sp.speaker: Emperor
sp.l: O my dear nephew,
Fly, fly the shambles, for thy turn is next.

sp.speaker: Edward.
sp.l: What, my imperial aunt? then break my heart.

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Brave prince be still; as I am nobly born,
There is no ill intended to thy person.

sp.speaker: Mentz.
sp.l: Where is my page? bring me my two hand sword.

sp.speaker: Tryer.
sp.l: What is the matter? is the court a fire

sp.speaker: Bran.
sp.l: Who's that? the emperor with his weapon drawn?

sp.speaker: Bohem.
sp.l: Though deadly sick yet am I forced to rise,
To know the reason of this hurly-burly .

sp.speaker: Alphon.
sp.l: Princes be silent, I will tell the cause,
Though suddenly a grining at my heart
Forbids my tongue his wanted course of speech.
See you this harlot, traitress to my life,
See you this murderer, stain to mine honour,
These twain I found together in my bed,
Shamefully committing lewd adultery,
And heinously conspiring all your deaths,
I mean your deaths, that are not dead already;
As for the King of Boheme and myself,
We are not of this world, we have our transports
Given in the bowl by this adulterous prince,
And lest the poison work too strong with me,
Before that I have warned you of your harms,
I will be brief in the relation.
That he hath stained my bed, these eyes have seen,
That he hath murdered two imperial Kings,
Our speedy deaths will be too sudden proof;
That he and she have bought and sold your lives,
To Saxon, Collen, and the English prince,
Their ensigns spread before the walls tomorrow
Will all too suddenly bid you defiance.
Now tell me princes have I not just cause,
To slay the murderer of so many souls?
